The Whole Ecosystem

NZILBB R, Stats, and Open Science Workshops

Joshua Wilson Black
joshua.black@canterbury.ac.nz

Te Kāhui Roro Reo | New Zealand Institute of Language, Brain and Behaviour

Te Whare Wānanga o Waitaha | University of Canterbury

Overview

R, Stats, and Open Science

  • R: a programming language for statistical computing.
  • Stats: modelling for the kinds of data used in NZILBB projects.
  • Open Science: a set of practices encouraging maximal openness in the scientific process (incl. planning, data, and aanalysis).

What are we doing here? Let’s go through each bit of the title of these workshops.

We’re learning about R. R is a programming language for statistical computing which is widely used in the sciences. It was created in New Zealand, at the University of Auckland, so there is some national pride at stake here.

R has a lot of friends, which enable us to produce publication-quality plots, tables, and even full papers or websites. I use R to make these slides. If you’re really perverse, you can even read your email in R.

We’ll be learning some basics of statistical models. This won’t be a statistics course, but some details will be important (always with a view to practical applications).

We’ll also try to use best practices for ‘open science’. This is a broad heading which includes a lot of things. One side is a response to the ‘replication crisis’ which became a big deal in the 2010s. We want the whole process and as many outputs as possible to be repeatable by other people so that they can be confident in our work. This has many other benefits: it helps us to return to old work, and reproducible work by others is much easier for us to build on.

Workshops

  • Aim: that you will be confident R (+) users with good open science practices.
  • Side benefit: lots of transferrable skills both in and outside academia.
  • Content: Responsive to what you will find useful and your experience.
  • Website: https://nzilbb.io/statistics_workshops/
  • Today: let’s learn what the tools are and get the set up.

The aim of these workshops is to make you confident users of R and of the whole open science ecosystem, who use good open science practices in your work.

Because much of this ‘ecosystem’ or ‘infrastructure’ is borrowed from the world of software development, it will have the additional benefit of giving you some transferrable skills.

The content is somewhat responsive to what will be useful to you. So let me know if there is anything in particular you’d like to cover.

NZILBB is multidisciplinary research centre, but it has a strong history in linguistics. Some of you might be less familiar with linguistic data. If so, I’m very happy to try to incorporate examples from your world. Just let me know.

I aim to make these increasingly ‘hands-on’, but it is usually useful for me to run through some content at the start of the workshop.

Last year, I introduced new technologies as-and-when relevant. I found this introduced set-up pain more frequently than I would like. I’ve decided this semester to front-load the pain and try to get everything we will use set up now.

The ‘Ecosystem’

Alright, here’s a wall of logos and names! Let’s have a quick look at what these are.

/

First, we have a cluster of logos concerning data analysis and presentation. Here we have R, the programming language, and RStudio a piece of software for interacting with R while engaged in data analysis.

Often things in the R world have hexagonal logos. Here we have a logo for the tidyverse, which is a set of packages for R, which extend it in many related ways. The chief developer of the tidyverse, Hadley Wickham, is also a New Zealander, just by the way. As an example of a package in the tidyverse, ggplot2 is very popular for making plots.

The other hexagonal tiles are two tools which help to produce things like these slides, papers, and websites about your projects. The chief advantage to us as researchers, is that both quarto and Rmarkdown allow us to combine the kind of thing we normally do: write lots of paragraphs, with code. We can explain our code in detail. This approach is sometimes called ‘literate programming’.

/

We now turn to some tools for ‘version control’ and ‘code sharing’. You might instead call this ‘git and friends’. What is ‘version control’? It comes from software development, where code is divided into different ‘versions’. We often do this informally, by giving files names like my_essay_0_2_JoshComments_Final_FINALFINAL.docx. This may be ‘brat’, but it is neither ‘demure’ nor ‘mindful’. In particular, it isn’t any way to share our work with other people. Git is a piece of software which keeps track of changes we make to our code and, indeed, anything we might want to store as part of a project. It also includes structures for collaborating with others in a controlled manner. You will likely hate git for a while, but you may very well come to love it.

GitHub and GitLab are platforms for hosting projects which use git for version control. I put them both here because GitHub is probally the most commonly used external service for hosting git repositories. But we also need to know about the version of GitLab which is hosted at the University of Canterbury. This is important for any project which might include sensitive data which you do not have permission to share with a third party.

/

I thought I’d add the best logo in the history of computing: the linguists in the room will recognise this as the logo for Praat, a piece of software for doing phonetic analysis. This is just an example of a discipline-specific tool. Many projects will require use of specific tools from your discipline which are external to R.

/

One aspect of Open Science is the pre-registration of hypotheses. All data sets have patterns in them. Finding a pattern in a data set you already have is not very impressive. Finding a pattern which supports a hypothesis in a data set you collected after making the hypothesis is impressive. Services now exist to enable you to privately register hypotheses and how you will test them. OSF.io, the open science framework, has a service for this. Aspredicted is an alternative.

/

Finally, GitHub isn’t really the best for hosting large data sets. The Open Science Framework is very useful for data hosting. It is also a good hub to combine all aspects of a research data project.

/

There are lots of ways that you might move between these tools.

/

Here’s one option. Perhaps you start by preregistering a hypothesis, then you go out and collect data which you have to process with some discipline-specific tool.

/

Then you move in to R and RStudio to do the rest of the data analysis. Perhaps you fit a statistical model.

/

Throughout the project you might use git and the University-internal GitLab to keep track of the development of your project and collaborate with others at UC.

/

Then you need a public version of your project to share, so you host your project code on GitHub.

/

And then host an anonymised version of your data set on OSF.io, along with a description of your project and a link to your GitHub ‘repository’ (the git name for your project folder)

/

Or here’s another possibility:

/

You get someone elses code and data from GitHub and OSF. Perhaps you would like to try the same methods with your own data.

/

You do a bit of processing in discipline-specific software to modify the data.

/

Then you host your modified ‘repository’ on GitHub.

/

Other paths are possible!

https://nzilbb.github.io/statistics_workshops/

Scroll down to ‘NZILBB induction’

We’ll go in a slightly different order

Check who has successfully followed the process?

We’re going to go through each of the things in the NZILBB induction.

R and friends

Installing R and R Studio

  1. Follow the steps here: https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/ OR
  2. Using the UC Software Centre if you are on a managed UC laptop.

Find out who is using what.

Open RStudio

  1. Type install.packages('usethis') into the ‘Console’.
  • Well done: you’ve installed your first package.
  • This package helps us to interact with GitHub and GitLab.

RStudio

  • RStudio is just one option for interacting with R.
  • Any text editor will do.
  • But RStudio is very well suited for data analysis.
    • esp. nice data-viewing and plot-viewing features.
    • We will mainly interact with git using RStudio.

Git and friends

Install git

  • Windows: download from https://git-scm.com/downloads/win.
    • If you are given an option to allow ‘3rd-party software’ say yes.
  • macOS: install ‘developer tools’ by opening the Terminal app and typing xcode-select --install
  • Linux: odds are you have it already. If not: https://git-scm.com/downloads/linux.

Create a GitHub account

  • https://github.com
  • We’ll need to know the email you used very soon.

Connect R and GitHub

usethis::use_git_config(
  user.name="YOUR NAME", 
  user.email="YOUR GITHUB ACCOUNT'S EMAIL ADDRESS"
)
  • Replace YOUR NAME with your name.
  • Replace YOUR GITHUB ACCOUNT'S EMAIL ADDRESS with the email you used to sign up to GitHub.
  • usethis::git_default_branch_configure()
  • usethis::create_github_token()
  • gitcreds::gitcreds_set()

Test it’s working

  1. Create a new GitHub ‘repository’.
    • Include a ‘README’ file, when given the option.
  2. Create an R project connected to GitHub:
    1. File > New Project...
    2. Select ‘Version Control’
    3. Enter the url of your GitHub repository.
  3. Modify the README file, “commit the change, the push to the remote”

The jargon takes a while…

The R and Git Bible: https://happygitwithr.com/

OSF.io

OSF.io

  1. Create an account at https://OSF.io
  2. Search for projects connected to your interests.
  3. What do they use OSF to share?

What’s next?

What’s next?

  3. Self-contained sessions, e.g.:

    • Git jargon and problem solving,
    • Plotting with ggplot2,
    • PCA
